subtitle: Hello and welcome back to Astral Doorway, my name is Gene and some of you have noticed
throughout my episodes I haven't made a specific video dedicated to just solely talking about
how to lucid dream and have asked me to make one so here it is - for those who don't know lucid
dreaming is where you suddenly realize that you're in a dream and begin to take control of yourself
and the dream, instead of the dream controlling you and with just little practice it is very
easy and i'm going to describe how to do it very simply ~ the reason i haven't made a video
just about lucid dreaming before is because the practice of astral projection naturally leads to
lucid dreams; this should be relatively easy to understand if you've watched my previous episodes
i'd probably be a bit of a hypocrite if i said learning lucy dreaming first isn't completely
necessary because when i first started out on all of this many years ago the first thing i
focused on was lucid dreams which i had hundreds of filling about two or three dream journals of
lucid experiences, this of course naturally helped me a lot when it came to understanding the deeper
practice of astral projection... and also in a way lucid dreaming is very nice for beginners because
there's less of that hardcore spiritual work on the ego to focus on that astral projection
usually challenges you with, the fun is in the endless possibilities of your own imagination
you know in lucid dreaming you are simply having fun within your own mind you're still
in the matrix, so to speak, you're awake aware but you're only awake and aware within your own dreams
not beyond them but still it's a fantastic opportunity to become familiar with interacting in
such a non-physical state while your physical body sleeps; if you want to understand the difference
between lucid dreams and astral projection more then just check out the video on the screen now
just to give a few examples of my own lucid dreams you know i've flown through mountain ranges, moved
through buildings across landscapes, moved entire planets across space, shape shifted, participated
in literal wars in my own mind representing my own conflicts in life, and of course engaged in various
conversations with my own subconscious through dream characters... the possibilities are endless and
there's lots of benefits to lucid dreaming one of the main benefits being you know getting to know
your own psychology at a deeper level so when i started i only really focused on three main things
which can be categorized into three simple steps, you may have heard of each step before but i'm
going to explain each one to help you understand why we do them and why they're so effective
and of course little tips here and there just to help you understand how to do each one
so number one: perform reality checks at least five times a day; a reality check literally checks and
confirms what environment we are in and whether we are dreaming or not a reality check is to attempt
to perform a specific action that is not possible to do while in physical limitation
dreams are non-physical environments and therefore there is no physical limitation to what you can do
more importantly performing reality checks trains the mind to get into the habit
of questioning whether you are dreaming or not you, know try to recall some of your most absurd dreams
right now; perhaps you were having a conversation with a camel while on a roller coaster - now think...
why did you not realize that it was a dream you didn't because you haven't trained your mind to
tell the difference between waking reality and dreaming reality; what is absurd is not the dream...
what is absurd is our inability to discern when we're in a ridiculous dream situation that has no
correlation with our physical waking life at all... so therefore this is where reality checks come
into play get into the habit of doing reality checks at least five times a day and especially
do them whenever you feel there's something strange going on throughout your daily life
so here's four solid effective reality checks i'm recommending, these reality checks are based
on testing the physical limitation of your environment directly... reality checks such as
reading the time or counting your fingers are not 100% effective or reliable i don't recommend them
you can easily be in a dream and count five fingers and be fooled and think you're awake
if you're going to invest time committing to a reality check then choose one of these four
i'm going to list now, from A to D, so A: Jump ~ you must jump with the intention of flying you must
really believe that you can in fact fly, even if it feels ridiculous to do while you're awake
almost expect that you will in fact fly don't assume you're in waking life
remember that in dreams you always assume you are in waking life so really consider
so if you can jump and you get pulled back down to the ground then you're awake but if you don't
go back to the ground and you stay floating in the air then you're obviously in a dream
flying in dreams is a lot of fun by the way it's quite a freeing experience, but just one issue
with this reality check is that you can't do it everywhere for example if you're at work or in
a meeting people would just of course ask what in the world are you doing so, reality check B
is: put your finger through the palm of your hand this one is a lot more discreet and you can do
it anywhere so simply attempt to push one of your index fingers through the palm of your other hand
if it passes through successfully then you're in a dream if it doesn't then you're awake, again
do this with conviction and real consideration that you could really be dreaming reality check C
is similar: try to extend one of your fingers, that's it, if you can stretch one of your fingers
and elongate it then you're in a dream if not then you're awake in your usual
physical life environment, and D: my most favorite and all-time used one
is the hold nose reality check i've spoken about this one before it involves pinching your nostrils
shut and then trying to inhale through your nose if you can breathe through your nose
while it's closed you're in a dream if not then you're awake unfortunately i've been
using this one less because of covid and having to wear a mask in various situations
regardless it's proved extremely effective for me personally and it's quite a strange sensation
every time to be able to breathe whilst holding your nose shut, this video is all time stamped
below by the way if you ever want to come back to any of the main steps or these reality checks,
so all of these reality checks test the boundaries of physical limitation and generally you should
choose one main one to commit to so that your body and mind can get into the habit of doing
it all the time, once you're successful with one then that's probably the one you're going to stick
with for the rest of your life, then of course you can also use one of the others depending on what's
more suitable during daily life situations you're in, whichever reality check you do you can also
mentally ask yourself; "Am I dreaming?"... don't answer the question back to yourself with your intellect
but use your senses and really look around your environment for at least a good 30 seconds; really
questioning and being skeptical of where you are and why you're doing whatever you're doing
even if you're in a really mundane average situation that you always do every day always
question your reality ~ now i'm not exaggerating when i say if you commit to just seriously
questioning your reality and doing reality checks this is enough to experience a lucid dream
quite quickly too, as many studies by psychologists clearly state: we dream about what we do during
the day therefore if you do enough reality checks during the day you will absolutely eventually find
yourself doing them in your dreams too, so that's the significance of step one, reality checks, but
of course we want to raise our chances as much as possible right? so let's combine this with step two
affirmations... these affirmations are a set of words that we emotionally affirm to ourselves deeply we
say this within the depths of our minds in order to believe with conviction that they will happen
we say these before sleep or as we're drifting off to sleep here are a set you can choose from
use one or as many as you like you'll get the point they're listed on the screen now...
"I will lucid dream in my sleep"... "I will realize that I am dreaming"... "I am dreaming"... "I always know when I am
dreaming"... "I will be awake in my dreams"... "I will lucid dream tonight"... "I am fully aware during my dreams"...
saying these mentally as you sleep and believing in them creates a sort of 'subconscious motivation'
a subconscious energy that will convince your mind to make you aware during your dreams
at the very least it will at least remind you to do a reality check that will of course lead you to
lucidity so the more you focus the more you remember about your desire to lucid dream
and the more you really believe that it will happen the more likely that it will, you know
don't underestimate the power of this sort of self-convincing and not just self-convincing but
also sending power to your subconscious to awaken this mantra, this affirmation, in action... you know
during the day in waking life you spend time and energy planning ahead for special events right?
for example you may have a presentation to give so then you begin thinking about it practicing
and visualizing and believing what and how you're going to deliver that presentation... all
of this work and effort trickles down into your subconscious mind and if you've prepared properly
the presentation will be a breeze because your subconscious is now doing most of the work for you
and so lucid dreaming is exactly the same; think of spending time doing affirmations,
which you could also call mantras, as investing energy which you'll use automatically later on
during sleep, so it can also be a good idea to sit up straight in a meditative position
and spend perhaps five up to maybe 10 minutes saying an affirmation, then lie down and you can
continue saying it as you drift off to sleep, this will help you to focus on saying it with
better attention and intention rather than just doing it mechanically and unconsciously right, now
it is possible to go straight into a lucid dream when you first sleep however it's far more likely
that it will happen during the stages of a REM sleep ~ R-E-M means 'rapid eye movement'
which is the stage of sleep where you dream the most vividly, it can differ between people and
situations but it typically happens or heightens anywhere between four to six hours of sleep, and so
step three is wake-back-to-bed and it's a popular practice in lucid dreaming teachings because it's
just so effective, wake-back-to-bed means to set an alarm before sleep to wake up in the middle
of the night, you stay awake for a little bit and then go back to sleep with the affirmations
and intention of lucid dreaming, you see when you first go to sleep our consciousness enters
very very deep states within our psyche in order to revitalize and balance us
and so it is more challenging to remember to become lucid or become conscious during dreams
in that time, however as our sleep cycle continues through the night our consciousness slowly becomes
more balanced and gradually begins to rise to the surface, and since our awareness is usually focused
on the surface experience of life, this is when we usually remember our dreams if you see on the
screen now all around here in this location around four to six hours of sleep is when we begin to
have these more impressionable or memorable dreams, we do dream throughout the night but this is where
it's the most vivid, the most active, and so we can take advantage of this 'high dream activity window'
by getting up in the middle of the night... so in terms of choosing when you're going to get up
in the middle of your sleep uh how many hours into your sleep you choose to set your alarm
may take some experimenting at first if you're new to this i'd say wake up around five hours and then
go back to sleep if you didn't have a lucid dream try four hours or six hours the following days
and then you should start to get a sense for when you dream most vividly, if you are extremely tired
when you wake up it could be a sign that you might be waking up too early, take into consideration
your age too generally younger people need more sleep so their REM cycles may occur
after perhaps seven hours of sleep that was certainly the case for me when i started lucid
dreaming at 18 years old, now the time older i find myself having more experiences after just five
hours of sleep, you will also have to experiment with how long you stay awake in the middle of
the night, it's important that you're able to fall back to sleep quickly with ease therefore i'd say
to begin with try staying up for five minutes perhaps go to the bathroom, drink some water...
if you can easily fall asleep while saying the affirmations then it might be a good time for
you and you may be even able to extend the time and perhaps next time you could stay up for seven
eight ten minutes you could also spend some time doing step two right? you could get up in the
middle of the night sit up straight and maybe for 10 minutes in a meditative position you can recite
the mantras, the affirmations; however if you struggle to fall back to sleep then
you should minimize how long you stay awake during the middle of the night and you should also
wake up earlier too so that you're more tired, more lethargic, and able to go to sleep easier
for some people it may even be effective to wake up after only three hours of sleep - i've
had lucid dreams after three hours of sleep too it's completely possible personally i can usually
wake up after around five or six hours and, i stay up, i stay awake for about 10 minutes this is my
personal timing with practice you'll find your own sweet spot so to summarize step 3 simply
set an alarm to wake you up in the middle of the night get out of bed for a few minutes sit down
somewhere and say the affirmations to yourself for a few minutes and you can also do a reality
check too and then go back to sleep with the intention of lucid dreaming you can also continue
to say the affirmations as you drift away to your dreams, you should easily be able to fall back to
sleep because your body still wants to rest as it hasn't finished its sleep cycle, but paradoxically
by waking up you boost these REM signals because your body starts to think it's time to wake up
but you've sort of tricked it now because you're basically telling your body: "yes I want to wake up,
but not physically"... okay so those are three very easy to follow practices and when combined
together make for a very high chance of having frequent lucid dreams, you can even have multiple
in one night, every night ~ don't doubt yourself it's simpler than you think it is possible to
even have a lucid dream tonight on your first attempt however if you don't you shouldn't be
disheartened as with anything worth the effort in life you need patience and if i had to give
a general amount of time to invest in to expect results as i know some of you will ask
i'd say give it at least three weeks until you start to see gradual results, assuming that you are
really doing all three steps combined every day and with that said also here's a very important
tip: keep a dream journal and write in it every morning, write down as much detail as possible
you can use an app for that as well for those who may be lazy with handwriting, and we all have our
phones nearers these days right; so as you do this make sure you spend at least a couple of minutes
every night before sleep reading your experiences back to yourself this will remind you of your
recent dream experiences and re-engage those parts of your brain associated with connecting
to dreams these parts of your brain are muscles to be used once you start recalling one or two dreams
every morning it's very easy to remember them all the time and in great detail ~ everyone dreams every
night even if you don't know it check out the video on the screen now if you want to learn more
about how to recall dreams in detail including a powerful mantra that you can use to recall them
effectively as soon as you wake up, which is another little tip, make sure that remembering
to recall your dreams is the very first thing you do as soon as you wake up -- okay so there are many
other techniques for lucid dreaming but if you're new to this i recommend taking it slow and simple
if you're still hungry for cramming your brain with excess information i will provide some useful
links and book recommendations below as well as a couple of dream journal apps where you can type or
voice record your experiences, they also have built in reminders to do reality checks, and also if you
have some techniques of your own to share or want to share your experiences please let everyone know
in the comments below... a quick shout out to Charles, L2K, Sam, Marco, Jesus, and Katie who have all joined
the Astral Doorway Patreon group and are part of the Discord group where we engage in meaningful
conversations about all things spiritual ~ if you'd like to join and in doing so support the channel
the link is in the description ~ below my name is Gene Hart and I'll see you in your lucid dreams!
